page.title: 03 FARMING
page.content: This rural area is undulating; highest point 74m. The chalk soil drains rapidly. There is some erosion caused by wind. Mustard is grown to plough in and help retain moisture. The farms are mostly arable, growing wheat, barley (for malting), sugar beet, potatoes, beans and peas, usually in a 5-year rotation. There is some oil-seed rape. Compound fertilisers are used: nitrogen, phosphate and potash. Nitrogen is not used on beans and peas. Crops are sprayed against aphids and maggots. Marketing is mostly through merchants in Cambridge and Bedford areas. Some produce is sold at Cambridge. Sugar beet is sent to the factory at Bury St Edmunds.
